title: How did the Nazis manage to feel no remorse while killing so many innocent people? - Quora

response.answer_text: How did the Nazis manage to feel no remorse while killing so many innocent people? One of the people who probably killed more people, as an individual pulling a trigger was a cook not assigned to do so. A low ranking German soldier who worked as a cook and a butcher wandered over while he was working making chow for some soldiers and he found they were shooting Jews. He dispatched animals regularly and took pride and considered it professional to do so humanely, with little suffering. To his horror, he saw soldiers flinching, he saw people twitching, suffering, some still standing, parts of their necks, jaws blown away, others dropped and in agony. He snatched up a pistol and began dispatching people to end this horror. He was quite good at it. He shot them in a precise place and they dropped. Other soldiers, glad to be relieved of the duty handed him freshly loaded pistols. He even knew where to stand as well as where to shoot, to avoid being sprayed with blood, bones, flesh, nerve, brain tissue, skin and hair. He single handedly dispatched untold people then he’d walk back and peel potatoes, which he also did right, removing no more potato than necessary, being spot on with the potato eyes. Units began requesting him and soon, dispatching people was what he did. He was so much in demand, that other soldiers volunteered to do his duty so he’d be free to humanely dispatch ‘undesireables’. He took satisfaction that as soon as he arrived, less suffering occurred. He considered himself humane, and considering what he’d witnessed, and what was happening, horrifically, in a way, he was. But he sped up the process and made it easier. And terribly, he accepted it needed to be done. they accepted it needed to be done and removed themselves from individual responsibility. Once you can condition people to accept something ‘must be done’, their humanity and sense of self can actually facilitate the process of dispatching people. Another horrific story concerned a German officer. Among a group of Jews about to be killed he saw a beautiful woman who he felt didn’t fit in-she didn’t look Jewish, and if she did, well, she was a beauty. He pulled her aside and checked and was saddened to confirm this wasn’t a clerical error, she was a full Jew who was slated to be killed. He accepted that, but he could help. He considered himself a gentleman as he pulled her away from the others. No humiliating processing for slaughter for this young beauty, no leering crude enlisted men would watch her be stripped an herded toward the slaughter. He spoke to her calmly and dispatched her himself and considered himself quite the gentleman for taking some extra steps. We find ways to like ourselves, us human beings, even when we’re inhuman, and inhumane.

The Nazi’s were criminals, gangsters, and conmen. They distorted Darwinism to make it fit their scapegoat policies based on racial purity. Other races especially the Jews were seen as Untermenschen or sub-human. If you believe that your society, your country is under threat from sub-humans and that you’re racially pure and under threat from these people, obviously it was a good excuse for dispatching anyone they felt was inferior to their master race. The Nazi’s managed to convince the public that the Jews were responsible for them losing WW1, and all the ills suffered by the German State thereafter. It didn’t matter or was conveniently forgotten that many Jewish people fought bravely in WW1 for the Kaiser. Not long into the Second World War, ordinary citizens would have been too scared not to go along with Nazi ideology. If you were seen to have a conscience, you’d be labeled a sympathizer. Much easier and safer to cheer the Brownshirts and SS on, or even join in. Hans and Sophie Scholl of Munich University printed and distributed leaflets protesting of the cruel treatment of Jews and the murdering of the Polish intelligentsia. Eventually, they were rounded up, tortured and put to death. Sophie Scholl confided to her cellmate that she believed that her execution (22nd February 1943) would lead to German students at the university rising up against the Nazi regime. On the day of their execution, German students did rise up and protest, but they protested in favour of the Nazi regime. Finally to be cruel without remorse was richly rewarded. Promotions, houses, and properties that had belonged to Jewish people were up for grabs. Officers were promised new estates in the east to be given out after the war. Whereas to be seen to have remorse was in Hitler's eyes, a sign of weakness. You’d risk at least a beating at worst a prison camp or a bullet.

They actually kinda did. Not really the high ranking ones except for maybe a few. Heinrich Himmler, the Reichsführer of the SS had some remorse.  When he witnessed a bullet failed to kill 2 women. Himmler cried out to execute them to put them out of their misery. Before 1941, the Nazis shot and killed civilians. They often had to drink alcohol during this to cope with the executions. The executions were taking tolls on their mental healths for killing these people.  Himmler realized that, and ordered gas chambers to be used. That way, soldiers (especially the Einsatzgruppen), wouldn't experience so much psychological burdens as compared to executing a mother and her children. In 1941, the mobile gas van was built. Civilians would be told that they are being transported. Once they got into the back, the door would seal and the exhaust port would release the car's exhaust into the sealed cabin.  The soldiers would wait 20 minutes to ensure that everyone in the back was dead. They would either use collaborators or some soldiers to take the bodies out and throw them into a mass grave. Not all Nazis felt no remorse when committing these crimes.

Hatred for Jews was prevalent in the beginning of 20th century even before Nazis came to power. Even Stalin was anti semite. During the rise to power Nazis were able to paint their enemies clearly. In the aftermath of the first world war Germany suffered severe economic hardships. The democracy in Weimar Republic was very fragile.Between 1919 and 1933 when is Adolf Hitler came to power there was a political turmoil. And the way Hitler was able to revive the economy through rearmament and public works and his tough stance against the Treaty of Versailles made people think that they needed a strong leader. Now coming back to the question, how they were able to feel no remorse, because much of the people involved in the killing of Jews and others believed in the Nazi ideology to the core. There are even stories of SS soldier on Eastern Front who was so fanatic that he kept on fighting even when his pants were on fire (literally). They believed that the war was a war of ideology and for the greater good of Europe not just Germany. They believed to the core that Jews and others were their enemies and it was their duty to protect their country against this enemy. On top of this was also the economic incentive that many SS soldiers would get land in the newly conquered eastern territories on which they will bread the next generation of dedicated German youth. They believed that what they are doing will someday be seen as a necessary evil in the history or maybe even celebrated and maybe that might have been the case if the allies lost. They thought that what they were doing was completely logical at the Nuremberg trials it was found that many Nazis had genius level IQ. And letters from some top level SS offiers like Henrich Himmler show his affectionate side towards his family which shows how logical they thought of their actions to be.

The `killers`, the Eisatzgruppen and extermination camp staff were especially selected. In many cases, SS officers selected the obvious psychopaths. But there was also primitive psychological profiling within the Wehrmacht, so that `sadists` could be assigned to work that required remorselessness, and worse, enjoyment of killing and torture. As the other answers attest, the process was made a lot easier by years of effective propaganda dehumanising `inferior races`. However, the reaction of German soldiers and citizens after the war to the films of the extermination camps shows how sincerely anguished most people were: it’s a huge gulf between scapegoating a race and industrial massacre.

A) The SS and German Police who did the mass shootings in the USSR had heard many years of Nazi hate propaganda. This poisoned their thinking. They believed in the traditional German principle of being obedient and following orders. Most got totally drunk to anesthetize themselves to the horror of shooting men, women, children, and babies. B) The SS who worked the gas chambers in death camps were sadistic volunteers who were fine with what they did. Besides the gassing, they also casually shot, tortured, or beat inmates with pleasure.

In the Nazi view, Jews+Roma weren’t really human beings to begin with.Thus killing them was no more considered murder than killing a fly or a mosquito.Now Poles,Serbs,Belorussans,and Russians were people (in their view) but inferior people-so killing them was a bit more difficult.But once you get into the killing business ,it becomes all the same.Thus they were able to kill them too-though perhaps not with the same enthusiasm.

There was a concerted and planned effort to depict non Aryans as a lower class of humans, and thus not deserving of the human considerations accorded to the supposed master race. A sentiment mirrored here today in the white supremacist, anti-Islam, and other nationalist movements in the US. Donald Trump draws much of his political support from this segment of society, and on occasion has served as an apologist for them.
